title: Right Perception Every Time: How Can I Make It Happen? | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: But to have the sustained perception is a challenge.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the challenge of maintaining a sustained spiritual perception.

segments.key_quote: Just like you hear what is good chanting, one seminar you hear, three, four days you chant well, then again it goes back.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of chanting and attending classes to illustrate the fleeting nature of initial spiritual inspiration and the need for sustained effort.

segments.key_quote: Practice means repeated contemplation on these truths.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of practice, defined as repeated contemplation and application of spiritual truths, to change one's default perception.

segments.key_quote: If you want to believe something, you need some reasons.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the process of intellectual contemplation, emphasizing the need for reasons and understanding to internalize new perceptions.

segments.key_quote: When you encounter something, then you have to apply that.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses applying new perceptions in life and provides specific guidance for Brahmacharis (celibate students) regarding interactions with women, emphasizing avoidance.

segments.key_quote: With respect to holy name, contemplate, apply, contemplate, apply, contemplate, apply.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that Brahmacharis should focus on changing their perception through contemplation and application in other areas, such as chanting the holy name.

segments.key_quote: If you don't use a car, even a brand new car, keep it there for 10 years, won't start.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a car and the principle of 'disuse atrophy' to explain how unused perceptions weaken and fade away, reinforcing the Brahmachari's path of detachment.

segments.key_quote: If you go on seeing female as enjoyable, enjoyable, enjoyable, it becomes empowered, empowered, empowered and one day you will feel, so enjoyable it is. It's all in the head.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of diabetes and insulin to illustrate how repeated contemplation and application amplify perceptions, both good and bad, emphasizing the power of the mind.

segments.key_quote: By repeated contemplation and repeated application, it gets strengthened. By starving it, it becomes weak and dead.
segments.summary: The speaker summarizes the process of strengthening or weakening perceptions through repeated contemplation and application or starvation, and suggests the authorized way for Brahmacharis to engage with potentially distracting concepts is through hearing Srimad Bhagavatam.
